_comment: Created by ianb on 30/01/2015 15:41:08 using v2.3
title: How has HbA1c target achievement for children with diabetes changed over time?
analysis_commentary:
There has been a decrease in the proportion of children with HbA1c <58mmol/mol in the last two years, from 17.4% to 15.8%. At the same time there has been a slight decline in the proportion of those who have HbA1c over 80mmol/mol from 26.4% in 2011/12 to 25.8% in 2012/13; however this figure still suggests that over one quarter of children and young people with diabetes have unacceptably high HbA1c. Approximately 60% of children have an HbA1c between 58 and 80 mmol/mol.

Overall, the Audit report found that only 8% of the variability in the mean HbA1c and 7% in the variability of the proportion with an HbA1c >80 mmol/mol across the paediatric diabetes units can be explained by factors such as ethnicity, social deprivation, gender, age and diabetes duration, suggesting that over 90% is likely to be explained by health service related factors (structure, resources, delivery of care).

In future analysis we would like to also include A&E visits and unplanned admissions for children and young people with diabetes.
data_source: National Paediatric Diabetes Audit, HQIP and RCPCH
